metadata.disclaimer: This FAQ is compiled from experiences shared by caregivers and patients in the ALS Care & Support India community. It is intended for educational purposes only and does NOT constitute medical advice. Every ALS patient's condition is unique. Always consult your neurologist, pulmonologist, or treating physician before making any medical decisions.

categories.name: Respiratory Care & BiPAP
categories.description: Critical respiratory support, BiPAP usage, and ventilator settings
categories.section_note: Important: Everyone with ALS should be prepared with BiPAP, suction machine, oxygen concentrator and ambu bag regardless of whether they need it now or not. No one knows when the emergency arrives. Keep these items ready at home BEFORE you need it urgently.

questions.question: What is BiPAP?
questions.answer:
BiPAP (Bilevel Positive Airway Pressure) is a non-invasive ventilator that helps breathing by providing two pressure levels:

• Provides higher pressure when breathing IN (IPAP), helps inflate lungs
• Provides lower pressure when breathing OUT (EPAP), helps push CO₂ out
• Gives rest to exhausted breathing muscles, preventing rapid decline

questions.question: When Does a PALS Need BiPAP, How to Decide?
questions.answer:
**Understanding the Core Problem**
In ALS, the breathing problem is NOT about getting oxygen IN, it's about getting CO₂ OUT. The diaphragm and chest muscles progressively weaken, losing their ability to push air out properly. This causes CO₂ (carbon dioxide) to accumulate in the blood, a condition called hypercapnia.

**Signs That Indicate BiPAP is Needed**

**The Hidden Warning Signs (Even with Normal SpO₂)**
• Cannot sleep at night / frequent position changes - waking up, turning sides many times
• SpO₂ dropping during deep sleep - check at night, not just daytime
• Difficulty sleeping flat, needs 2-3 pillows/recliner
• Morning headaches
• High pulse (100+) at rest
• Daytime drowsiness, fatigue, gasping
• Breathlessness while eating or talking
• High Respiratory rate
questions.warning: If you see any 2-3 of these signs, discuss starting the use of BiPAP with your doctor and experienced CALS immediately.

questions.question: How BiPAP Usage Progresses Over Time? How many hours should PALS use BiPAP daily?
questions.answer:
**The Natural Progression**
BiPAP usage is not fixed, it increases as the disease progresses. This is normal and expected. The key is following the body's needs, not any fixed timeline.

In the initial stage, BiPAP is needed only during nighttime sleep for 8-10 hours. BiPAP usage typically begins with nighttime-only support (8-10 hours) when oxygen levels drop during deep sleep, but as the disease progresses, the requirement gradually increases.

**Common Misunderstanding:** "Using BiPAP more will make PALS dependent on it faster."

**Reality:** The disease makes PALS dependent, not the BiPAP. Delaying BiPAP use actually accelerates progression because exhausted muscles deteriorate faster.

When the pals requests more BiPAP time, proceed with their decision, as they instinctively know what their respiratory system needs. When 24x7 usage becomes necessary, it is critical to discuss tracheostomy as a more sustainable long-term solution. Discuss with the experienced cals and doctors.
questions.warning: Everyone with ALS should be prepared with BiPAP regardless of whether they need it now or not. No one knows when the emergency arrives. Keep BiPAP ready at home BEFORE you need it urgently.

questions.question: Can early BiPAP help delay tracheostomy?
questions.answer:
**YES!** Community experience shows that PALS who started BiPAP early were able to delay tracheostomy by 6 months to 2+ years in many cases. Some PALS have continued on BiPAP for years without needing tracheostomy.

**How Early BiPAP Helps**
• BiPAP gives the diaphragm muscles 'rest' by helping with breathing
• Less muscle fatigue means slower deterioration
• Prevents respiratory muscle exhaustion, reduces stress on weak muscles
• Maintains CO₂ clearance
• Emergency situations are prevented
• PALS can maintain a better quality of life

**To Maximize BiPAP Effectiveness:**
• Start at first respiratory symptoms
• Don't skip nighttime use
• Get settings optimized by experienced pals
• Use suction machine / cough assist for better secretion management

**Remember:** Using BiPAP is not 'giving up' - it's being smart about preserving muscle strength and energy, and avoiding emergencies. The less fatigue we give to the body, the better we manage ALS.

questions.question: When Should we use oxygen concentrator along with BiPAP?
questions.answer:
**When Oxygen May Be Needed (WITH BiPAP):**
• SpO₂ remains < 90 despite optimized BiPAP
• During acute illness (pneumonia)

**Safe Oxygen Use Protocol:**
• Always with BiPAP - Connect O₂ to BiPAP's oxygen port
• Low flow - Usually 2-4 L/min

questions.question: When Is Tracheostomy Needed? What are the decision criteria?
questions.answer:
**Understanding the Decision**
Tracheostomy is one of the biggest decisions in ALS care. It involves surgically creating an opening in the windpipe (trachea) for direct ventilation, bypassing the nose and mouth entirely.

Community experience shows it is needed in two scenarios:

**Scenario 1: Planned Tracheostomy (Preferred)**
This is when you have time to prepare and plan properly. Tracheostomy becomes necessary when:
• PALS is 24x7 dependent on BiPAP (not just night time use)
• The normal airway (nose/throat) has become too weak
• PALS is unable to maintain SpO₂ even with BiPAP (SpO₂ dropping below 90)
• ABG (Arterial Blood Gas) shows high CO₂ despite BiPAP support
• Unable to clear secretions from lungs, leading to frequent chest congestion and infections

**Scenario 2: Emergency Tracheostomy**
This happens when there is no time to plan. Emergency tracheostomy typically happens in these urgent circumstances:
• A sudden, critical drop in oxygen saturation occurs due to acute infection, aspiration, or respiratory failure lead to emergency tracheostomy in ICU
• The decision to start non-invasive BiPAP was delayed too long, and the diaphragm muscles have deteriorated beyond the point where even non-invasive BiPAP is not sufficient leaving no option to return to non-invasive support

**Conditional Guidance**
• IF PALS uses BiPAP only at night + maintains good SpO₂ during day → THEN Continue monitoring, not ready for tracheostomy yet
• IF PALS requires BiPAP 24x7 + still struggling to maintain SpO₂ → THEN This is your time to act, plan tracheostomy proactively
• IF Frequent pneumonia + BiPAP becoming insufficient → THEN Urgent discussion needed, don't wait for emergency
• IF PALS already intubated in ICU → THEN Tracheostomy is safest option after intubation

**Community Perspectives**
"Tracheostomy need arises when PALS become 24x7 dependent on BiPAP, the normal airway has become weaker, plus they are unable to maintain saturation even with BiPAP, then tracheostomy is a must."

"Many PALS continue on NIV BiPAP for years with good secretion management and cough assist use."
questions.recommendation: For tracheostomy, talk to experienced members of the ALSCAS group, talk to as many caregivers as you want. Decision should be yours, your family's, and PALS's together.

questions.question: How to delay or avoid emergency tracheostomy?
questions.answer:
The goal is to either delay tracheostomy as long as possible, or if it becomes necessary, to have it done in a planned manner rather than an emergency.

**Ways to Delay Tracheostomy**
• Use BiPAP early and consistently - This gives rest to breathing muscles and delays the need for tracheostomy by months to years
• Use suction machine and Cough Assist machine regularly - This helps clear secretions from lungs and prevents lung infections
• Get PEG early - This prevents aspiration from oral feeding, which is a major cause of pneumonia
• Treat respiratory infections aggressively - Don't let a small infection become pneumonia
• Good secretion management - Regular nebulization, suctioning, and chest physiotherapy

**Avoid the Emergency Scenario**
• Keep BiPAP ready before you need it
• Keep oxygen concentrator, ambu bag ready and learn to use them
• Have cough assist available if possible
• Act quickly at first signs of infection - don't wait
• Have a plan with your doctor and experienced cals for what to do in emergencies
• Consider home ICU setup for managing care at home

The planned approach is always better. It gives time to prepare mentally, financially, and set up proper home care.

questions.question: Why Do Families Delay BiPAP Even After Knowing the Signs?
questions.answer:
**The "Positivity Trap"**
Being positive is essential - it gives strength to both PALS and CALS.

When we are in the caregiver role, we are often overwhelmed with anxiety and fear. We truly believe our PALS will never need devices like BiPAP. Even after reading messages and knowing the signs, actually making the decision feels very different - these are new, unfamiliar things that can feel scary.

What seems obvious to those already using BiPAP is not obvious to those facing the decision for the first time. It's only after you start using it that you realize: "This wasn't as difficult as I feared, and I wish we had started earlier."

This is completely natural. But positivity can sometimes become a barrier to timely action. At least one family member should stay practical when it comes to making important decisions.

**Common thoughts that delay the decision:**
• "Our PALS will never need these devices" - but this denial delays preparation, and waiting often leads to emergency.
• "SpO₂ is stable, everything is fine" - but normal SpO₂ can hide dangerous CO₂ buildup and breathing difficulty.
• "BiPAP might make the muscles weaker or create dependency" - but the opposite is true. Delaying BiPAP exhausts muscles faster.

**The Reality:** In ALS, the less fatigue we give to breathing muscles, the better.

**Waiting for Doctors to Decide**
Many families wait for doctors to tell them when to start BiPAP. This can be risky because even experienced doctors may have limited ALS experience and might focus only on SpO₂ levels, missing early warning signs like difficulty sleeping flat or morning headaches. Ideally, they should also assess diaphragm muscle strength, not just lung condition.

questions.question: What are HME filters and why are they important?
questions.answer:
HME (Heat and Moisture Exchanger) filters are important for tracheostomy patients:

• Warm and moisturize the air entering the lungs
• Protect from dust and particles
• Should be changed regularly

When breathing through a tracheostomy, the air bypasses the nose and throat which normally warm and humidify the air. HME filters help replicate this function, keeping the airways moist and protected.

questions.question: How do we balance positivity with practical decision-making in ALS care?
questions.answer:
**Being positive is important for both PALS and CALS.** It helps us stay strong and hopeful. But at the same time, at least one family member should stay practical when making important decisions.

**The Challenge:**
As PALS and CALS, we often feel we will beat this disease. We don't want to think negatively. We believe we'll never need BiPAP, PEG tube, or any supportive devices. But sometimes, too much positivity keeps us in a kind of delusion, hoping some magic will happen.

**The Reality:**
We also worry that using supportive devices will make us dependent and destroy the body's natural capacity. This thinking is partially correct, but it can make us delay important decisions and miss the right time to act.

**Key Insight:** In ALS, we should not overexert the body. Using support devices like BiPAP, wheelchair, and feeding tubes actually helps **reduce muscle fatigue and preserves strength for longer**.

**Community Wisdom:**
• Early BiPAP can delay tracheostomy by months to years
• Early PEG prevents emergencies
• Don't wait for SpO2 to drop - watch for symptoms
• Using support devices helps preserve strength, not weaken it
• Plan ahead rather than react to emergencies
• You know your PALS best - trust your observations

categories.name: Nutrition & PEG Tube
categories.description: PEG tube placement, feeding protocols, and nutritional guidance

questions.question: When should we consider a feeding tube (PEG)?
questions.answer:
PEG (Percutaneous Endoscopic Gastrostomy) is a feeding tube placed directly into the stomach. The same logic as BiPAP applies here: early adaptation to feeding support is very important. Don't wait for emergencies.

**Signs That It's Time to Discuss Feeding Tube**
• Meal takes too long → If eating a normal meal takes more time
• Difficulty swallowing → Food feels stuck or hard to swallow
• Coughing or choking while eating or drinking
• Fear of eating → PALS avoids food because of choking episodes
• Weight loss
• Exhaustion after meals → Eating should not make you tired
• Repeated aspiration → Food may be going into windpipe which can lead to lung infection and emergency

| Delaying PEG | Early PEG |
|--------------|------------|
| High risk of aspiration pneumonia | Lungs are protected |
| Malnutrition and weakness | Nutrition is maintained |
| Each meal becomes stressful | Nutrition without stress |
| Emergency PEG is riskier | Planned PEG is safer |
| Weight loss is hard to reverse | Weight is maintained |
questions.warning: Repeated aspiration causes lung infections. Aspiration pneumonia can lead to emergency. We should also be careful to get the PEG surgery done at the time when PALS have good respiratory efforts. They should be able to sustain 20 minutes of endoscopy procedure.

questions.question: Can PALS still eat by mouth after PEG?
questions.answer:
This is one of the most common concerns. The answer is **YES**. Early PEG often allows PALS to enjoy oral eating longer because they're not exhausted and stressed by trying to meet all nutritional needs by mouth.

**Having a feeding tube does NOT mean no oral eating:**
• Many PALS continue to eat favorite foods by mouth for pleasure
• The tube provides nutrition without the stress and aspiration risk
• It's supplementary support, not a complete replacement
• PALS can still taste food → just not depend on oral eating for all nutrition
questions.warning: Repeated aspiration causes lung infections. Aspiration pneumonia can lead to emergency. We should also be careful to get the PEG surgery done at the time when PALS have good respiratory efforts. They should be able to sustain 20 minutes of endoscopy procedure.

questions.question: How to thicken liquids for swallowing difficulty?
questions.answer:
**When PALS has difficulty swallowing thin liquids:**

• **Commercial thickeners** like Thick-It can be used
• **Natural options:** Sattu, chia seeds soaked in water
• **Coconut water** is often easier to swallow than plain water
• Start with nectar-thick consistency, adjust as needed

**Thickening Levels:**
• Nectar thick - flows like nectar
• Honey thick - flows like honey
• Pudding thick - holds its shape

**Tips:**
• Always test temperature before giving
• Small sips are safer than large gulps
• Position PALS upright during and after drinks

categories.name: Daily Care & Complications
categories.description: Constipation, bedsores, drooling, and routine care

questions.question: How Do I Manage Excessive Saliva/Drooling?
questions.answer:
**Understanding the Problem**
**Common Misunderstanding:** The body is producing too much saliva.

**Reality:** Saliva production is normal. The swallowing muscles have weakened, making it difficult to clear saliva. This causes pooling, drooling, skin irritation, and aspiration risk.

**Management Strategies**

**Active Wiping**
Keep a soft cloth handy at all times. Wipe saliva from mouth and face frequently.

**Positioning**
Keep head slightly elevated. Side-lying helps drainage. Avoid lying flat as it increases pooling.

**Oral Suctioning**
Use Yankauer suction tip with a portable machine (Yuwell or similar). Provides immediate relief through frequent, gentle oral suctioning. Keep suction machine nearby at all times.

**Oral Care**
Maintain excellent dental hygiene and keep the mouth moist with frequent sips of water (if safe to swallow) or mouth spray to prevent thick, sticky secretions.

**Medications (Consult Doctor)**
Glycopyrrolate → Reduces secretions (use cautiously, can thicken chest secretions).

**Absorbent Products**
Power Drool bibs/pads (available from Romsons).

**Dietary Changes**
Reduce dairy intake (can thicken saliva).

questions.question: Is glycopyrrolate safe for reducing saliva?
questions.answer:
**Understanding the Medication**
Glycopyrrolate (brand names: Robinul, Glycate) is an anticholinergic that reduces saliva production. It's commonly prescribed for ALS-related saliva management.

**Benefits:**
• Reduces saliva production
• Can significantly decrease drooling

**Risks/Side Effects:**
• Thickens chest secretions (major concern in ALS)
• Dry mouth, dry cough in chest
• PALS may experience chest discomfort due to dry cough
questions.warning: Use glycopyrrolate cautiously. Monitor for thickened secretions and discuss alternatives with your doctor if side effects become problematic.

questions.question: How to manage constipation and bowel movements in a bedridden PALS?
questions.answer:
Constipation is very common in ALS due to reduced mobility, medications, reduced fiber/fluid intake, and weak supporting muscles for stool passing.

**Treatment Based on Severity**

| Severity | Duration | Treatment |
|----------|----------|------------|
| Mild | 1-2 days no stool | High fiber, more fluids, Cremaffin, isagbol |
| Moderate | 2-3 days no stool | Lactulose syrup, Cremalax 5mg, Polyethylene Glycol |
| Severe | 3+ days no stool | Cremalax 10mg, Suppository, Enema if needed |

**Note:** Polyethylene Glycol (PEG laxative) is highly recommended by community members. It softens stool without causing cramps or diarrhea. Cremaffin is a gentle option for regular use. Avoid Cremaffin Plus for regular use as it can cause dependency.

**Dietary Management**
• High fiber diet → fruits, vegetables, flax seeds daily
• Include natural laxatives in feeds: papaya, prunes, soaked figs, isabgol (psyllium husk) with milk/water
• Adequate hydration → 1500-2000 ml fluids per day
• Regular meal times

**Oral Medications & Supplements**
• Laxatives: Laxopeg (PEG 3350), Movicol, Cremaffin Plus are commonly used
• Probiotics: Can help maintain gut health
• Ayurvedic options: Nityam tablet for regular usage
• Natural options: Amla juice, Triphala, or Harde

**Medication Review**
Review medications regularly → Gabapentin, painkillers and excessive protein intake may cause constipation.

**About Enema**
Enema has its own pros and cons. Pros → immediate relief. Cons → can cause dehydration and sometimes leads to diarrhea.

Enema gives immediate relief when other methods haven't worked, but use it sparingly. Plain water enema is safer than other types.

questions.question: How to prevent bedsores?
questions.answer:
**Prevention is Better Than Cure:** Bedsores are much easier to prevent than to treat. Once they develop, they can be very difficult to heal.

**Prevention Steps:**
• **Use an Air Mattress:** A dynamic air mattress that automatically inflates and deflates different sections is essential. Make sure the pump is always on and working.
• **Change Position Every 2 Hours (Non-Negotiable):** Proper back care is a must.
• **AbZorb powder on lower back and buttocks** → Keeps skin dry
• **Cold-pressed coconut oil** → Apply on back and pressure points daily
• **Water cushion bag for tailbone area** → Very helpful for sitting
• **Keep skin dry** → Moisture promotes sores

**Products Commonly Used**
• Air mattress → Romsons or similar
• AbZorb powder/Cetaphil → Available at pharmacies
• Coconut oil → Cold-pressed is preferred
questions.warning: If a bedsore develops → consult doctor immediately. Deep bedsores can be very serious and difficult to heal.

categories.name: Equipment & Home ICU Setup
categories.description: Essential equipment, power backup, and home ICU setup guidance

questions.question: What Equipment Do We Need as ALS Progresses?
questions.answer:
**Important:** Every PALS should have BiPAP, suction machine, oxygen concentrator and ambu bag ready. You don't know when an emergency comes. Keep these items at home BEFORE you need them.

ALS needs different equipment at different stages. Get equipment BEFORE you need it urgently. This stops crisis situations.

**Equipment by Stage**

**Early Stage**
• Walker, wheelchair
• Shower chair, grab bars, raised toilet seat
• Non-slip mats

**Mid Stage**
• Hospital bed (adjustable height)
• Portable suction machine
• Air mattress (stops bedsores)
• Communication aids (alphabet board, eye tracker)

**Advanced Stage**
• BiPAP machine → don't wait for emergency
• Pulse oximeter → monitor SpO₂ regularly
• Cough assist machine → clears secretions
• UPS/Inverter → power backup is critical
• Ambu bag → manual backup for emergencies

**If PALS has tracheostomy:** Ventilator with backup, suction machine, oxygen concentrator + backup cylinder, and tracheostomy supplies.
questions.warning: Everyone with ALS should be prepared with BiPAP, suction machine, oxygen concentrator and ambu bag regardless of whether they need it now or not. No one knows when the emergency arrives. Keep these items ready at home BEFORE you need it urgently.

questions.question: How to Set Up a Home ICU Room for BiPAP + Tracheostomy?
questions.answer:
Setting up a home ICU room needs planning. Keep things simple and organized.

**Equipment You Need**

| Category | Items |
|----------|-------|
| Ventilation | Ventilator/BiPAP, Catheter mount, HME filter, Bacteria filter, Circuit pipes, Whisper swivel, Ambu bag |
| Oxygen | Oxygen concentrator, Backup oxygen cylinder |
| Suction | Suction machine, Vacuum set (Yankauer), Suction catheters, Normal saline, Syringes (5ml, 10ml) |
| Nebulization | Nebulizer machine, T-section, Normal saline, Levolin, Mucomix, Budecort |
| Monitoring | Multipara monitor, Pulse oximeter, BP cuff, Thermometer |
| Trach Care | Gauze swabs, Betadine, Sterile gloves, Scissors, Spare TT tube |
| Comfort | Recliner bed, Air mattress, Bedside table |

**Room Setup Tips**
• CCTV camera: give access to family members
• PALS comfort: TV, Alexa, AC help with mental well-being
• Test equipment: Check all equipment works regularly
• Keep organized: Have backup supplies ready and easy to find

**Backup Items (Always Ready)**

| Category | Backups Needed |
|----------|----------------|
| Ventilation | Spare TT tube (same size), Backup BiPAP/ventilator, Extra circuits & filters |
| Suction | Second suction machine, Extra catheters |
| Power | UPS + Inverter + Generator |
| Feeding | Backup PEG feeding tube, Syringes |

questions.question: Will using a power wheelchair or lift make the PALS weaker faster?
questions.answer:
**No. This is a common misconception.**

The muscles affected by ALS are already diseased and cannot be strengthened through exercise. Conserving energy by using assistive devices—such as a power wheelchair, mechanical lift, or supportive braces—actually helps the PALS maintain energy for essential activities like breathing, swallowing, and communicating.

**Key Insight:** Using support devices helps **preserve strength**, not weaken it.

**Benefits of assistive devices:**
• Reduces muscle fatigue
• Preserves energy for vital functions
• Improves quality of life
• Allows continued participation in activities
• Reduces fall risk

categories.name: Understanding ALS Basics
categories.description: Fundamental information about ALS, terminology, and disease progression

questions.question: What do PALS and CALS mean?
questions.answer:
**PALS** = Person/Patient with ALS (the patient themselves)
**CALS** = Caregiver of person with ALS (family members, hired help)

These terms are commonly used in ALS support communities worldwide.

questions.question: How do I know what stage my PALS is at?
questions.answer:
ALS progression varies, but here are general indicators:

**Early Stage:**
• Can walk (possibly with support)
• Can eat normally or with minor difficulty
• Can breathe independently, SpO2 stays above 95%
• Speech is clear
• Mostly independent with some help needed

**Middle Stage:**
• Wheelchair dependent or very limited walking
• Eating takes 30-45+ minutes, some choking
• May need BiPAP at night, SpO2 drops sometimes
• Speech becoming unclear
• Needs help with most activities

**Advanced Stage:**
• Bed-bound or fully wheelchair dependent
• On feeding tube (PEG/Ryles)
• BiPAP most of the day or on tracheostomy
• Cannot speak or very limited
• Needs 24/7 care for everything

questions.question: Just diagnosed - what should we do first?
questions.answer:
**Immediate Steps:**

1. **Confirm Diagnosis:** Consult 3-4 neurologists to confirm and rule out mimic diseases. Request tests for CPK Total, Acetylcholine receptor, MUSK antibody, ANA profile

2. **Genetic Testing:** If familial form suspected, consider genetic testing for specific gene mutations

3. **Join Support Group:** Connect with ALS Care & Support India community for guidance

4. **Focus on Nutrition:**
   • Include high protein (Ensure, whey protein)
   • Test Vitamin D and B12 levels - keep in upper range
   • Consider ashwagandha, Vitamin D & C supplements

5. **Gentle Exercise:** Daily light exercise is beneficial. Avoid strenuous physiotherapy or hard massage

6. **Prepare Emotionally:** Maintain positive environment at home

7. **Start Planning:** Discuss BiPAP, PEG, and other decisions early - don't wait for emergencies

categories.name: Emergency Protocols
categories.description: What to do in emergency situations - SpO2 drops, power failure, equipment failure

questions.question: SpO2 is dropping! What do I do?
questions.answer:
**IMMEDIATE Steps:**

1. **Give Ambu bag immediately** - provides instant relief

2. **Ask PALS** (if able) where they feel blockage - chest, throat, or balloon area

3. **Check ventilator** for disconnections or kinks

4. **If wet secretions:** NS 1-2ml + Ambu 5-6 pumps + Suction

5. **If dry cough:** Start nebulization with Levolin, continue Ambu support

6. **Tracheostomy patients:** Always do subglottic port suction

7. **Repeat cycle:** Ambu → Suction → Check SpO2 until >94%

if_then.then: Continue aggressive Ambu + Suction, consider calling emergency
Nebulize with Inhalex or Mucinac to thin them
2ml NS + 8-10 firm Ambu squeezes, may need tube change

questions.warning: SpO2 below 85% for more than 2-3 minutes despite intervention - call for medical help

questions.question: Power cut at night! BiPAP stopped. What's the emergency plan?
questions.answer:
**Immediate Actions:**

1. **Start manual Ambu bagging** if PALS on 24/7 ventilation
2. Check inverter - is it working? Battery may have died
3. Keep PALS sitting up (not lying flat)
4. Monitor SpO2

**Proper Setup You MUST Have:**

| Equipment | Cost | Purpose |
|-----------|------|----------|
| Home Inverter (2KVA minimum) | ₹15,000-30,000 | 4-6 hours backup |
| Generator (2-3 KVA) | ₹25,000-50,000 | Extended outages |
| Portable Battery Pack | ₹15,000-25,000 | Short outages/travel |
| Ambu Bag | ₹800-2,500 | Manual backup - no power needed |
| Oxygen Cylinder | ₹5,000-8,000 | Concentrator needs power, cylinder doesn't |

**Pro Tip:** Apply for essential/medical connection from electricity board. Medical connections get priority restoration.
questions.warning: Everyone in household should know how to use Ambu bag!

categories.name: Caregiver Support
categories.description: Preventing burnout, managing stress, and getting support

questions.question: How can family caregivers prevent burnout?
questions.answer:
**Shift Management:**
• Never do 24/7 care alone
• Arrange shifts among family or paid help
• Even 4-6 hours uninterrupted rest is crucial

**Support Network:**
• Join ALS Care & Support WhatsApp groups
• Connect with other caregivers who understand
• Don't isolate yourself

**Self-Care Basics:**
• Maintain your own health appointments
• Get adequate sleep (even if broken)
• Eat properly
• Exercise if possible

**Emotional Support:**
• It's okay to feel frustrated, sad, overwhelmed
• Consider professional counseling
• Share feelings with trusted people
perspectives: You cannot pour from an empty cup
Taking care of yourself IS taking care of your PALS
questions.warning: Persistent depression, anxiety, or inability to cope - seek professional help immediately

key_principles: Being positive is important, but at least one family member should stay practical for timely decisions
Early BiPAP can delay tracheostomy by months to years
Early PEG prevents emergencies and is safer than emergency PEG
Don't wait for SpO2 to drop - watch for symptoms like difficulty sleeping flat
Using support devices helps preserve strength, not weaken it
Plan ahead rather than react to emergencies
Involve PALS in decisions - they understand their body best
Ambu is your best friend - when in doubt, give Ambu
You are not alone - community is here to support
